Installation guide for PixelExperience 12.1+ on raphael/raphaelin
ROM: Download links for raphael can be found here: PixelExperience site
Latest firmware: Download respective latest firmware from here:
Redmi K20 Pro India Latest Firmware
Mi 9T Pro / Redmi K20 Pro Latest Firmware(Pick your region accordingly)
Recovery:
From Android 12.1 onwards, PE will be switching over to FBEv2 and F2FS filesystem. This means, generic TWRP/OrangeFox recoveries won't work for flashing the ROM.
However, you might TWRP initially to get the required OFox flashed. Get the latest TWRP from here.
Download OrangeFox from either of the options:
Android File Host- by Pranav Talmale
Direct download
(Optional, NOT Recommended) You can flash a DFE zip to remain decrypted, but I would strongly advice against it, unless you have the need to be decrypted and understand the risks of it.
Assuming ADB and fastboot are installed. Following commands are in linux format, might have to make some changes for Windows/Mac, YMMV.
Click on the trash/garbage bin at the bottom of OFox to get to the Wipe menu.
Connect your phone to PC with USB debugging enabled.
Enjoy the ROM, cheers!
Flash PixelExperience:
Flash the OFox recovery and the phone will auto reboot to OFox recovery.
Flash the PixelExperience zip.
Flashing firmware (Optional, but recommended):
Format/Wipe before install:
Getting to fastboot/recovery:
In a terminal, run: adb reboot bootloader and this will bring you to the fastboot menu.
In the Wipe tab, select/tick only Cache and Data options and Wipe them.
Incase you get stuck even after these steps, do checkout the Telegram group for raphael PE and seek help there. Be nice and respectful when asking for help.
Make a NAND backup, and only continue if you know what you are doing. I am not responsible for anything that happens to you/your device.
Now in the Format Data tab, type 'yes' and format.
Now run: fastboot boot twrp-3.7.0_9-0-raphael.img(the twrp file name will be the file you downloaded from Step 1)
Once in TWRP, (if your storage isn't mounted, mount it and then) transfer your Ofox-R11.1_1-FBEv2.zip file onto your storage.
Reboot to System and you should now be booting PixelExperience successfully.
Transfer the firmware file you downloaded onto the storage and flash it.
Transfer the PixelExperience zip file onto your storage.
Guide to setup Instance scheduler to schedule your EC2 hours

When you have EC2 instances which are running when not needed (outside of work hours, on holidays, etc.) and billing you for it, Instance Scheduler will help you cut down on these costs by reducing the uptime of the server instance by shutting it down with a schedule but also conveniently bringing it back when needed (as scheduled).

As the instance is stopping, some of your services might not boot up automatically upon restart of the instance, add them to your startup script. This would depend for each of the service you want to start. Some services might give you a startup script/command, so do check them out.
Change the options inside the office-hours period as per the image, you can edit the timings and weekdays as you need.
Change the options inside the seattle-office-hours schedule as per the image, while changing the name, description, and timezone as you need.
Check if it is working:
DynamoDB Setup:
EC2 Tags:
Enjoy saving $$$, cheers!
Ensure you're on the correct region or you will end up creating the job in the wrong region.
Frequency depends on what you would schedule your timtings as. If you're doing something like 08:00 to 18:00, then I think a 60 minute frequency is good enough.
Head over to DynamoDB and click on the Tables option in the left sidebar.
Head over to the AWS Instance Scheduler Page and click on the Launch in the AWS Console option.

In Configure stack options page, I decided to keep everything default, you could add a role, if you already have or need something specific, for CloudFormation to use, but it'll create it's own role if you keep it empty.

In Specify Stack Details page, give your CloudFormation Stack a name like dev-server-scheduler, and your Instance Scheduler a tag name like dev-scheduler. Set the default time zone to your time zone, this would help you avoid converting times later.
In the list, find the table which as ConfigTable in the name. Open that table and click on the Explore table items button.
In the next page, just verify details and acknowledge the role creation for CloudFormation and it'll start creation of your CloudFormation Stack.
In the table, you'll find multiple period and schedules. We'll use the seattle-office-hours schedule and office-hours period for our purpose.
Just check the instance state outside work hours to ensure it is stopped and during the next day, your instance starts up automatically.
On that page, you could change any options you want, but we'll keep the defaults and click Next.
Once this is done, head over to EC2 and inside your instance, go to Actions Instance Settings Manage Tags.
Save the tags.

You could enable CloudWatch logs and metrics if you need. Do add Started tags and Stopped tags, this would help you differentiate between Manual starts of the instance vs Instance Scheduler's.

You'll need to add a couple of tags here as per the image, but ensure to change the names as per your setup from previous steps. Note: The tag key should be the same name as the CloudFormation Stack for the instance scheduler. The tag key for my setup is dev-scheduler
